On 9/7/05, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> I'm actually=
 not completely sure what the word "clamp" means. Does
> it mean you are do=
ing dynamic thresholding in the style of my NEAT
> system, or does it mean =
you literally stop speciation from
> progressing after some number already =
exist?  (I guess Derek or you
> may be able to answer this question) My dyn=
amic thresholding is
> constantly moving towards a target number by moving =
the
> compatibility threshold, which doesn't seem like a "clamp" exactly,
>=
 so I think clamping may be a third option.

Okay, not sure "clamped" is a =
good word either, or that I even
understood exactly what Ken's code was doi=
ng.

I remember early on when we were working on our implementation, and
we=
re specifically working on some of the visualization tools, I saw
the speci=
ation graphic in Ken's 2002 paper, and it looked like for a
population of 1=
50 there were something like 8 species.  We hadn't
really tuned our compabi=
lity threshold so we were getting way more
species than this.

I thought th=
at in an email exchange Ken said that he set a maximum
number of species (t=
his is what I was referring to as "clamping" the
number of species).  It so=
unds though, in this discussion, that it
actually works by restricting the =
maximum number of members each
species can have, which would in practice wo=
uld very much the same way
I would guess.

It's interesting that you brough=
t this up.  We're going to be looking
a lot more closely at our population =
dynamics in the coming months. 
We've had discussions on this list about ki=
lling off stagnating
species in order to add more dynamism to the search al=
gorithm.  That
is something else we currently haven't implemented.  So we'd=
 like to
take a closer look at what's going there, but yeah, these issues a=
re
still pretty hazy.

Derek
